description.narrative:
1. Two state level FP workshops organized with the aim of advocating to policymakers, interacting with township level health teams, and identifying technical assistance needs. Also, in at least two states, identified gaps will be filled in training and information needs for FP, with a focus on new or under-used methods such as postpartum intrauterine devices (IUD) and contraceptive implants
2. A data collection exercise on youth sexual and reproductive health (SRH) knowledge, attitudes, and practices conducted, followed by the design of a pilot demonstration to improve adolescent and youth sexual and reproductive health (AYSRH) at one township
3. A side event on youth SRH service delivery strategies and policy recommendations in Myanmar conducted at the International Conference on Family Planning in Indonesia in November 2015, with discussions documented and disseminated through policy dialogues and follow-up
4. A financial contribution will be made to the 8th Asia Pacific Conference on Reproductive and Sexual Health and Rights (8APCRSHR) to enable youth participation and support Myanmar state-level participants’ scholarships to the conference; side events on FP will be organized.

This project addresses gaps in the areas of 1) policy and enabling environment development, 2) access to services, and 3) demand generation. Our proposed strategy is to select a number of family planning (FP) model townships in consultation with the Minitry of Health and implement pilot approaches that address these gaps. For effective FP service delivery in communities, this project will take an approach that emphasizes overcoming barriers to health service delivery at the township level. This includes exploring possibilities for integrating FP into existing maternal, newborn, and child health (MNCH) and other health services supported by other donors, or strengthening existing health data collection or utilization efforts.
